Award.AwardTitle: Validating contrasting terrestrial climate-sensitive Pliocene deposits through high resolution modeling of paleo-environments in the Transantarctic Mountains
Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit:
Neogene sediment records recovered by ANDRILL suggest multiple events of open water conditions and elevated sea surface temperatures at times when terrestrial data from the McMurdo Dry Valleys indicate hyper arid, cold, desert conditions. Interpretation of the ANDRILL data suggests the West Antarctic Ice Sheet is highly sensitive to changes in Pliocene sea surface temperatures and this conclusion has been supported by recent Global Circulation Model results for the early to mid Pliocene. The PIs propose to model paleo-ice configurations and warm orbits associated with a WAIS collapse to assess potential climate change in East Antarctica. During such episodes of polar warmth they propose to answer: What is the limit of ablation along the East Antarctic Ice Sheet?; Are relict landforms in the Dry Valleys susceptible to modification from increase in maximum summertime temperatures?; and Is there sufficient increase in minimum wintertime temperatures to sustain a tundra environment in the Dry Valleys? Integration of depositional records and model outputs have the potential to test the performance of numerical models currently under development as part of ANDRILL; reconcile inconsistencies between marine and terrestrial paleoclimate records in high Southern Latitudes; and improve understanding of Antarctic climate and ice volume sensitivity to forcing for both the East Antarctic and West Antarctic Ice Sheets.

Broader impacts:
Results from this study have the potential to be used widely by the research community. Outreach to local elementary schools from other funded efforts will continue and be extended to homeschooled students. A Post Doc will be supported as part of this award.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Empirical data show that the earth’s temperature is currently increasing. It is documented that the maximum warming occurs at the poles placing the world’s ice sheets at risk. Melting of these ice sheets results in 10s of meters of sea level rise placing coastal communities at risk. One of the best means for predicting future sensitivity of the Antarctic Ice Sheets to a warming climate is to investigate how the Antarctic Ice Sheets have responded during past interglacials. Here we specifically focus on the stability of East Antarctic Ice Sheet (EAIS), an ice sheet which is primarily grounded above sea level and is the largest ice sheet on the planet. If it were to melt, sea level would rise approximately 60 meters. 

Scientists have debated about the stability of EAIS. There is abundant terrestrial evidence, in the form of stable landforms in the McMurdo Dry Valleys of Antarctic, which suggest continuous cold atmospheric temperatures in Antarctica and imply long-term EAIS stability (stable for >15 million years). However, recent offshore drilling efforts by ANDRILL (an Antarctic Drilling Program) suggest possible melting of the smaller West Antarctic Ice Sheet (WAIS) due to warming ocean temperatures during recent interglacials (as recent as ~ 1 million years ago). This research aimed at investigating how a loss of WAIS would influence climate in Antarctica, the terrestrial stable landforms in the McMurdo Dry Valleys, and the surface melting potential of EAIS. Specifically, we investigated how would the terrestrial climate (i.e. climate in the McMurdo Dry Valleys) change if WAIS were absent and would it become too warm for preservation of temperature sensitive landforms for millions of years?

We ran Global Circulation Models (GCMs) as input into a regional climate model that we specifically tuned to simulate paleoenvironmental conditions. The regional climate model we believe is the first to allow input for past or future orbital forcings. We also adjusted boundary conditions and land use to simulate topography and ice configuration during an interglacial at ~1 million years ago when WAIS presumably was greatly diminished or absent.

Initial model runs investigated the influence of orbital forcing. Model results suggest the McMurdo Dry Valleys would experience warming of a few degrees Celsius as a result of a warmer southern hemisphere orbit (specifically during Marine Isotope Stage 31). The elevated temperatures during the summer months (December, January, February) appear insufficient to cause instability of terrestrial landforms in the McMurdo Dry Valleys in this scenario. Secondary runs adjusted carbon dioxide levels between 280 ppm and 400 ppm (i.e. present day). Even at the higher CO2 level, the model results support continuous cold polar conditions and minimal EAIS surface melt. The final simulation modeled a scenario with the warm orbit, CO2 at 400 ppm, and a new ice configuration (i.e. the no WAIS scenario). Summer temperatures in the McMurdo Dry Valleys (especially at high elevation) showed only a moderate increase of less than a couple degrees Celsius from the previous model run. Sustained cold temperatures in the McMurdo Dry Valleys mountainous regions were seemingly due to the high topographic relief and possibly the prevailing winds from the polar plateau. Precipitation along the Transantarctic Mountains was predicted to increase with warmer temperatures; increased precipitation occurred when sea ice or ice shelves were limited allowing for multiple open bodies of water to exist upwind from the Transantarctic Mountains. Increased precipitation may result in minor advancement of regional alpine glacial systems even though temperatures may have been slightly warmer.
